Challenge: The HCP may be hesitant to prescribe PrEP due to concerns about adherence and the need for effective monitoring strategies.

Rep Approach: • Discuss the importance of assessing renal function (eGFR, CrCl) and urinalysis before PrEP initiation and monitoring every 3-6 months during treatment to identify potential renal impairment, as recommended for safe PrEP prescribing [HIV-PREP-SAFETY-003].  • Highlight the benefits of long-acting injectable PrEP options, such as Apretude (cabotegravir long-acting injectable), which can improve adherence for patients facing daily pill burden challenges, as indicated in the FDA label [HIV-PREP-APRETUDE-004].  • Emphasize the need for regular follow-up and monitoring to ensure sustained viral suppression and adherence to PrEP, as demonstrated in the DISCOVER Trial and the FDA label for Descovy PrEP [HIV-PREP-TAF-002].

Impact: By discussing renal function monitoring, long-acting injectable PrEP options, and regular follow-up, the HCP will be more likely to feel confident in prescribing PrEP and monitoring adherence, ultimately leading to improved patient outcomes.
